coredata.dc:title: Geminate recombination after binary photoionization
coredata.dc:creator: Burshtein, A.I.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A kinetic law is derived for geminate recombination which results from binary encounters of photoexcited donor with electron acceptors in liquid solution. The initial distribution over ion pair separation is found for both slow and fast ionization. When ionization is controlled by diffusion, the spherical reaction layer, where ions are mainly born, is shown to have a greater radius than the closest-approach distance.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 194, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 June 1992 Geminate recombination after binary photoionization A.I. Burshtein ' Department of Chemical Physics, Weizmann Institute ofScience, Rehovot 76100, Israel Received 18 December 1991; in final form 24 April 1992 A kinetic law is derived for geminate recombination which results from binary encounters of photoexcited donor with electron acceptors in liquid solution. The initial distribution over ion pair separation is found for both slow and fast ionization. When ionization is controlled by diffusion, the spherical reaction layer, where ions are mainly born, is shown to have a greater radius than the closest-approach distance. 1. Introduction Remote electron transfer is a cause of superdiffusional reaction rates of highly exothermic binary ionization, following pulse excitation of a solution according to the kinetic scheme D*+A-*[D+...A-] . The effective reaction radius of the quenching via ionization, RQ, is greater than the closest-approach distance between the partners (Ro) and increases with the viscosity of the solution [ 1,2 ]. The final explanation of this implies that ionization occurs in a narrow spherical layer which divides the space into a normal zone outside and an inverted zone inside it [ 2,3 ] . The ions created with a distant-dependent ionization rate Wt (r) have either to recombine or to be separated by diffusion, according to the kinetic scheme [D...A].- [D+...A-]~D++A- . (2) This geminate recombination (or separation) was a subject of separate study in numerous works assuming that ions were born at contact [4-6]. The conventional kinetic description of the process used in these works was recently shown to be inappropriate Correspondence to: A.I. Burshtein, Department of Chemical Physics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 76100, Israel. ' Meyerhoff Fellow. On leave from Institute of Chemical Kinetics and Combustion, Novosibirsk, Russia. 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. at high viscosities (small separation quantum yields) [ 7 ]. The consistent diffusional description of the recombination with a rate WR ( r) was used instead [ 8 ] and the characteristic time of the process was shown to have opposite viscosity dependence when ions were born in contact or far away. To find out where ions really are at the beginning of the geminate process the latter must be considered together with precursor ionization. It is an aim of this Letter to link together the backward and forward electron transfer in the frame of the unified encounter theory based on given unimolecular rates of both processes W,(r) and WR(r). 2. Encounter theory The theory of noncontact reactions accelerated by diffusion was first proposed for energy transfer [911 ] but was soon recognized as a general approach to binary reactions in solutions [ 12,13 ]. Later, it was rederived [ 14 ) and applied to electron [ 15 J or "exchange" transfer [ 16 ] in liquids. If the acceptor concentration c is small enough [ 13 J the density of excited donors N obeys the kinetic equation of nonMarkovian encounter theory [ 17 ] 1V- - kl ( t ) cN-N zp . Here zp is the lifetime of the excitation and kl (t)= I WI (r)n(r, t) d'r (3) (4) 247 Volume 194, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 June 1992 is the nonstationary ionization reaction constant in the binary approximation. To find it one has to solve the equation for the pair distribution function n=Ddn-W,(r)n, with initial and reflecting boundary conditions n(r,0)=1 an 0, ar d = (5) (6) where D is a coefficient of a relative diffusion of neutral reagents. Actually n (r, t) is the distribution of excitations around a single acceptor with a growing hole in the centre. The radius of the hole does not exceed the effective radius of the stationary ionization RQ. In the binary approximation RQ must be much less than the average distance between acceptors. If ion pairs do not move and do not recombine then their density P(t) increases with time according to an equation which follows from eq. At ultrafast ionization n =1, n = iD. On the contrary, at slow ionization n--~TDns. Hence in the former case (34) F(r)-'fo(r) whereas for latter case F(r)-,f(r), de- fined in eq. (27). In between, the ionization is not static but it proceeds in nonstationary way and the distribution is determined by the Laplace transform of eq. (5) . 7. Conclusions For exothermic ionization the maximum of the distribution may be removed from contact even at ultrafast ionization if fo(r) as well as W(r) is of belllike shape [3]. But even if W(r) is exponential, the charges created by moderate and slow ionization appear in a thin layer where W(r) significantly over- Volume 194, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 26 June 1992 W- 0 ti (A) t a~ Z Ro (B) i i i I i Ro Rq r Fig. 2. Space dependence of W (bold line) and n for ultrafast (a), nonstationary (b) and quasistationary (c) ionization (A) and corresponding initial distributions (B). laps with n(r) (fig. 2). The radius of the layer increases with TD/T1 until it approaches the vicinity of RQ. The reaction sphere radius may be shifted out of contact either by using long-lived donors or by increasing the viscosity (decreasing T,=RQ2 ID). The actual initial distribution may easily be found for any given W(r) from eq. ( 39 ) and the Laplace transform of eq. ( 5 ). References [ 1 ] A.I. Burshtein, E.I. Kapinus, LYu. Kucherova and V.A. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A kinetic law is derived for geminate recombination which results from binary encounters of photoexcited donor with electron acceptors in liquid solution. The initial distribution over ion pair separation is found for both slow and fast ionization. When ionization is controlled by diffusion, the spherical reaction layer, where ions are mainly born, is shown to have a greater radius than the closest-approach distance.
